response.answer_text: Criminology is the study of the law enforcement and criminal justice system. A person looking for a career in criminal justice will likely first seek to earn a criminology degree. While criminal justice and criminology are certainly related fields, they are not identical. Criminologists look at a broad range of topics related to crime. They are dedicated to studying not only the causes of crime but the social impact as well. In essence, criminologists look at every conceivable aspect of deviant behavior. It includes the impacts of crime on individual victims and their families, society at large, and even criminals themselves. Some of the specific areas that criminology covers include: Frequency of crimesLocation of crimesCauses of crimesTypes of crimesSocial and individual consequences of crimesSocial reactions to crimeIndividual reactions to crimeGovernmental reactions to crimeThe end goal of criminology, is to determine the root causes of criminal behavior and to develop effective and humane means for preventing it. These goals have produced several schools of thought within the discipline, each of which looks at different factors involved in deviant behavior and comes to different conclusions about how best to approach the issues.

Criminology as the name defines is the study of crime and criminals. But Criminology is subject which tries go into the various related aspects of a crime or criminal. Criminology is closely associated with Sociology because sociology is the study of society. (Crime happens in the society and criminals are part of the society like any other person or citizen). Criminology is a diverse and inter disciplinary field of study which has associations and related to various fields like Sociology, Psychology, Political Science, Economics, Law, Psychiatry, etc…,. It is considered closely related to sociology, psychology because criminology studies the crime and criminals by considering various social, Behavioural, psychological, economical related causes which are behind the happening of a crime and a criminal who commits the crime. Criminology studies a Criminal from various aspects like personal and family background, Social and Cultural background, Economical background, Behavioural issues, Medical history, etc..,.and studies the crime from various causation theories and draws up conclusion on a criminal or crime based upon the various schools of thought and theories of criminology. Overall if you’re really interested to know about various types and causes of crimes and how, when and why people turn into criminals in detail. Then, Criminology would be a nice and interesting course if you want to pursue it academically. I’m not a scholar or faculty. I just have a Diploma in Criminology and Correctional Administration along with Bachelor’s Degree in Sociology. I would never miss a criminology class in college and would have lengthy discussions with the faculty even after the class timings. Number of students for the diploma course were very few.
